responses.user_utterance: Cider vinegar? Isn't it acidic?
responses.resolved_utterance: Cider vinegar is good for acid reflux? Isn't it acidic?
responses.response: It might seem counter-productive to add more acid to your already struggling system, but apple cider vinegar can make you feel so much better. Sometimes acid reflux can be caused by a lack of acid or lower amounts of acid in your system. Adding a bit of acidic apple cider vinegar can stop these problems before they occur. Combine 3 tsps or 1 tablespoon of raw, unfiltered, apple cider vinegar with 6-8 ounces of fresh water and drink before a meal. You can repeat before each meal or even 3-4 times throughout the day. Notes: If you notice that your acid reflux is worsening, discontinue this home remedy.

responses.user_utterance: Why does it happen? Does it have a reason?
responses.resolved_utterance: Why does acid reflux happen? Does acid reflux have a reason?
responses.response: Acid reflux is a condition that occurs when the lower esophageal sphincter (LES)--a muscle between the stomach and esophagus-- malfunctions, allowing stomach acid to flow back into the esophagus. This can cause a burning sensation in your heart and chest, which we often refer to as "heartburn." Over time, prolonged acid reflux can cause damage to the esophagus and potentially lead to the chronic form of the condition called GERD. Acid reflux happens due to improper functioning of the LES. Acid reflux normally happens when we eat certain foods that stimulate excess acid production; however, for some people, genetics plays a role in reflux. Eating large meals, lying down straight after eating, or snacking close to bedtime are also common triggers of reflux. Being overweight means that you are more likely to suffer from reflux because of increased pressure on your stomach, which can force open the valve after a meal. Some people find that acid reflux is worse when they are stressed. Acid reflux also happens due to a weakness of the sphincter muscle, or when the stomach produces too much acid and not enough protective mucus. There is also something called a hiatus hernia; due to a gap in the diaphragm, parts of the stomach can move into the chest, which increases the risk of reflux.

responses.user_utterance: I have a deadline approaching. Could that be related? Are there any ODC medications?
responses.resolved_utterance: I have a deadline approaching. Could that be related? Are there any ODC medications for acid reflux?
responses.response: Sorry to hear that, yes it could certainly be a reason for your problem. There are specific types of medicines to help treat acid reflux. These include a class of medicines called proton pump inhibitors. Some examples of PPIs available over-the-counter include: Esomeprazole, Omeprazole, and Lansoprazole. There's also a type of medication called H2 blockers available over-the-counter to help with acid reflux. These include: Cimetidine, Famotidine, Nizatidine, and Ranitidine.

responses.user_utterance: How are these two compared?
responses.resolved_utterance: How are proton pump inhibitors and H2 blockers compared?
responses.response: H2 blockers are less expensive and seem to be safer than the PPI medications. In a 2016 study led by Dr. Morgan Grams of Johns Hopkins University, people who use PPIs are more likely to develop chronic kidney disease compared to those who take other types of heartburn medication.

responses.user_utterance: Good to know, I was told my kidney function is slightly impaired, but I meant in terms of how they work.
responses.resolved_utterance: Good to know, I was told my kidney function is slightly impaired, but I meant how PPI and H2 blockers are different in terms of how they work.
responses.response: Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) and H2 blockers both reduce stomach acid, but they work in different ways. PPIs block the final step of acid production by irreversibly inhibiting the proton pump (H+/K+-ATPase) in stomach lining cells. This leads to stronger and longer-lasting acid suppression. H2 blockers, like ranitidine, work earlier in the process by blocking histamine-2 receptors, which only partially reduces acid production. Because PPIs act at the final stage and bind irreversibly, they are generally more effective than H2 blockers in reducing stomach acid.

Also, Cimetidine, Famotidine, Nizatidine, and Ranitidine are examples of famous H2 blockers.

Instead of going out for dinner or seeing a movie, go ahead and plan to spend a day at the park or go for a hike at a local park. Start playing sports again. responses.response: Sour coffee is a symptom of under-extraction during the brewing process, which means the grind has to be fine enough to allow the extraction at a rapid pace. You will end up with sour coffee if your water is not hot enough to extract the good flavors from the beans. You can turn the tide by using a higher coffee-to-water ratio. Specifically, you'll need to brew more coffee with less water. Stale coffee beans are victims of oxidation, and they often have a sharp lemony flavor that's simply off. If you brew these beans, you'll end up with sour coffee.

responses.response: There are four different types of coffee beans in the world. 1) Arabica makes up most coffee grown at present, accounting for about 60% of commercial coffee production. It originated in Ethiopia, where it grows wild. However, people first cultivated it in Yemen, and it is from there that it takes its name. Arabica beans have sweeter and more complex flavors than Robusta coffee beans, which is why they currently dominate coffee markets, especially specialty coffee markets. Arabica coffee beans have a bright acidity, medium body, and multiple layers of flavor. They are well suited to be brewed pour-over style, which lets their subtleties shine more than espresso or immersion brewing. 2) Robusta is the second most commonly grown type of coffee bean. Robusta's name comes from being more robust than the Arabica plants, which is why you can grow it in a broader range of environments. Therefore, it is less prone to disease. However, despite these advantages, it remains less popular than Arabica because its flavors and aromas aren't as desirable. Robusta beans are known for having a darker, earthier flavor, and for this reason, they are most often subjected to a darker roast to better match their natural character. Robusta beans also have nearly twice the caffeine of Arabica beans. While Robusta beans are generally considered lower quality than Arabica, this is not necessarily the case. There are a growing number of farmers and processors working to develop high-quality Robusta beans and Robusta-Arabica hybrids. 3) Liberica beans make up only about 2% of the world's current coffee crop. Once upon a time, this varietal was far more critical after disease wiped out much of the world's Arabica supply. Arabica has since made a comeback, and Liberica production has primarily ceased. However, that may change in the future, as climate change makes it increasingly challenging to produce the more sensitive Arabica plants reliably. Liberica coffee has a unique flavor, pairing floral and fruity notes with a deep smokiness that some describe as woody. It has a full-bodied, reminiscent of Robusta coffee. It's not to everyone's taste, but there are some exceptional Liberica coffees to be had when done right. 4) Excelsa has recently been reclassified as a type of Liberica coffee because it thrives in the same conditions and grows a similarly tall tree. But the actual coffee it produces is vastly different. It has a much fruitier character than Liberica, with a tart acidity that makes it popular for adding complexity to coffee blends. Excelsa coffee makes up only about 7% of the current coffee market. Still, given its appealing flavor profile and the fact that it is nearly as resilient and productive as Robusta, this seems likely to grow. Much like Robusta, Excelsa coffee has been regarded as poor quality, but this is more due to poor growing and processing practices than the bean itself. With the proper care, Excelsa has the potential to be specialty-grade coffee.

It's also important to note that a large amount of coffee's natural caffeine content is lost as roasting continues. The longer you cook or roast something, the fewer nutrients remain. As you roast coffee for longer, the chlorogenic acid begins to seep out. Chlorogenic acid is considered an antioxidant, which means it repairs your body and protects you from diseases like cancer. There are four common roast levels: Light roasts (also called cinnamon roasts) retain the most caffeine and acidity. You'll taste more of the floral or fruity notes of the bean and get a thinner body. Medium roasts: This is the most balanced of the roasts. You'll get some acidity with more sweetness and aroma. They're the most common roast in the United States, which has led to the nickname American roast. Medium-dark roasts: Also called city roasts, these have the bittersweet aftertaste most people associate with coffee. They have a high aroma and sweetness with almost no acidity, and may have some visible oil on the surface of the beans. Dark roasts: You may also hear this called a French roast or Italian roast. These beans are nearly black and very oily, and you'll taste more of the roast than the bean in the cup. Dark roasts have the least caffeine and acid and tend to be very bitter, with a full body and lingering aftertaste. The Medium-dark roasts can be a good option for you as they have no acidity.

responses.resolved_utterance: Hi, I have pain in my finger, can you help me?

I climb outdoors.

responses.user_utterance: Not sure, but it might be.
responses.resolved_utterance: Not sure whether the pain in my finger is related to my regular climbing activities, but it might be.
responses.response: Finger pain after climbing is pretty common, climber's finger is one of the most common climbing injuries within the sport of rock climbing, accounting for about 30% of finger injuries seen in climbers. Whether it's problematic depends on a few factors, including the intensity of the pain and the location. Can you tell me where exactly the pain is located? Is it in the pulley, the joint, or the tendon? I can also provide you with a detailed anatomy of the finger if you cannot localize it yourself.
relevant_ptkbs: I am climbing regularly for the past 3 years.
I climb outdoors.

responses.user_utterance: Yes please, I don't really know, it could be the tendon.
responses.resolved_utterance: I have pain in my finger possibly related to a climbing session. I don't know where in my finger, maybe the tendon, tell me about the anatomy of the finger as I cannot localize the pain myself.
responses.response: That's totally fair, it can be hard to tell, so let's break down the anatomy of the finger. Three bones and three hinged joints make up the finger. Ligaments connect and stabilize the bones, while tendons connect muscle to bone, transferring to the bone any forces created by the muscles. Flexor tendons in the fingers attach to muscles in the forearms that pull on the tendons, bend the fingers, and allow us to crimp. Connective tissue encases the tendons, forming a sheath with five thickened areas that create the annular pulleys (A1, A2, A3, A4, and A5), which keep the tendon close to the bone when bending the fingers.

responses.user_utterance: Thanks, but please relate your answer to my pain? How is the pain on those different areas?
responses.resolved_utterance: Thanks, but please relate your answer to my pain in my finger which is possibly related to a climbing session? How is the pain in tendon, pulley, and joints when having injuries in the hands?
responses.response: Yes sure. Most common climbing injuries actually come from pulley, sometimes with a loud "pop" and then significant swelling and pain. For A2 pulley injuries, the most common pulley injury for climbers, the pain usually arises at the base of the finger and is noticeable when trying to straighten or bend the finger. For A2-A4 ruptures, there may be bowstringing, bulging at the base of the finger, which can be detected by resisting finger bending at the fingertip. Those are usually associated with pain on the front of the finger. Otherwise, if you see difficulties with bending your finger, this can be due to damage on the tendon, it can be the case if you also have an open injury or a cut on the open side of your hand. Finally, if you feel that the pain is more on the side of the finger, then this might be the collateral ligaments of the fingers.

responses.user_utterance: I have pain in the front of the finger, especially when crimping, but I cannot see any bowstring, can this still be the A2 pulley?
responses.resolved_utterance: I have pain in the front of the finger, especially when crimping, but I cannot see any bowstring, can this still be the A2 pulley?
responses.response: When you bend your finger, normally the tendon stays snug against the bone because the pulleys hold it down. In very serious cases, if you have a complete rupture of the pulley (especially A2), the tendon lifts off the bone, forming a visible or palpable "bowstring" under the skin. However, you can also have just a strain on the A2 pulley, with pain when crimping, which is less serious than the complete rupture, but still needs some rest. It is a good sign if you don't have a visible bowstring.

responses.user_utterance: I understand, what are the next steps?
responses.resolved_utterance: I understand, what are the next steps if I have pain in my A2 pulley as a climber?
responses.response: If you have pain in your A2 pulley as a climber, here is what to do next, depending on the severity of the injury: Grade 1: Pulley sprain. A partial tear of a single pulley. Solution: No need for immobilization. Begin gentle range-of-motion exercises, bend the finger until it feels tight, hold for 2-3 seconds, relax, and repeat 10 times for several sessions each day. Now perform the same exercise, only straighten the finger. Avoid pushing through pain. Grade 2: Complete A4 or partial A2, A3 tear/rupture. Either the A4 pulley is completely torn, or A2 and A3 are both partially torn. Solution: One to two weeks of immobilization with a finger-immobilization splint or a pulley-protection splint. Gentle range-of-motion exercises. If it persists, you can seek a diagnosis from a climbing-knowledgeable physician or orthopaedic surgeon, who can assess the damage with an ultrasound or MRI. This will help determine the level of care needed, as well as confirm and check possible damage to the rest of your hand.

responses.user_utterance: I don't think I want to do an MRI. Anyway, what are the risks if I don't rest?
responses.resolved_utterance: I don't think I want to do an MRI. Anyway, what are the risk if I don't rest with A2 pulley injuries?
responses.response: You risk damaging the pulley even more, which can be very dangerous and lead to surgery. From past patients that went through the surgery, most of them complained of reduced finger dexterity while performing their daily activities and work, and not being able to perform as they use to at climbing. This is not advisable. Even without going as far as the surgery, it can lead to a worsening of the tear, a bowstring, over-compensation from another part of your hand and risk of further injuries. Your body might also do inadequate healing with excessive scar tissue and limit your flexibility in the future.
relevant_ptkbs: I am climbing regularly for the past 3 years.

responses.user_utterance: I will take it slow and take a few weeks off. What are some advice for when I start again?
responses.resolved_utterance: I will take it slow and take a few weeks off climbing. What is some advice for when I start again climbing after A2 pulley injuries?
responses.response: That's a good spirit. It is advised to spend the first weeks climbing relatively easy routes with big holds, good footholds and keeping sessions short. Stay away from overhangs and campus boards. You can return to full-force climbing if easy climbing yields no pain. Continue taping (it will also serve as a mental note of the previous injury) and avoid tweaky crimps and pockets for several months. Collagen supplements may also help the pulley recover faster by providing much needed building block nutrients. It is also good to re-start in indoor climbing rather than outdoor directly, as low temperatures increase the risk of injury.
relevant_ptkbs: I climb outdoors.

responses.user_utterance: I don't like taking supplements. How to tape?
responses.resolved_utterance: I don't like taking supplements. How to tape after A2 pulley injury?
responses.response: Yes, it is totally understandable, many people prefer not to take supplements. When it comes to taping, it can be a helpful way to protect an injured pulley. Since taping restricts finger movement, it prevents you from using the injured area in ways that could make the damage worse, making it a generally safe and recommended approach. According to Dave Saunders, a physiotherapist and climbing injury specialist known for his work on hand and finger injuries in climbers, effective taping for A2 and A3 pulley injuries should limit the finger's ability to bend at the middle joint. To apply the tape correctly, note the three creases on the front of your finger, starting from the base. With your finger straight, begin taping from halfway between the first and second crease and finish halfway between the second and third, overlapping the tape by 50%. Once taped, you'll notice you can't crimp anymore, which is actually a good thing for healing. The goal is to restrict the range of motion at the injured joint so that crimping becomes impossible, protecting the pulley during recovery.
relevant_ptkbs: I am climbing regularly for the past 3 years.

responses.user_utterance: What about the H shape?
responses.resolved_utterance: What about H-taping? How to tape after A2 pulley injury?
responses.response: H-taping is generally more effective than standard circumferential taping for supporting injured finger pulleys, especially the A2 and A3. To apply an H-tape correctly, start with a piece of athletic tape about 4 inches long and the full width of the roll. From each end, tear lengthwise inward, stopping about half an inch before reaching the centre, so you are left with a narrow "bridge" between two tails. This creates the "H" shape. Place the central bridge of the tape over the palmar side (the inner surface) of the middle joint of the injured finger. Start by wrapping the two tails around the section of the finger closer to the palm (proximal phalanx), anchoring it firmly. Then, slightly bend the finger, about 30 degrees at the joint, and wrap the other two tails around the section of the finger beyond the joint (middle phalanx). This technique limits extension and flexion at the joint, providing mechanical support to reduce stress on the injured pulley while still allowing controlled movement for rehab.

responses.user_utterance: Should I tape other fingers as well when training?
responses.resolved_utterance: Should I tape all fingers when training or only the injured ones?
responses.response: Research suggests that preventative taping of healthy fingers is a bad idea. It will not provide any meaningful level of support to healthy pulleys (Schweizer, 2000). Worse, it may actually lead to injury, as your pulleys may not get the proper stress they need to continue strengthening and keep pace with your muscle growth throughout your training. There should be a balance, and you should not rely excessively on taping. If you want to reduce the risk of A2 pulley injuries, you can take several training precautions. First, strengthen your fingers progressively using open-hand positions on hang boards, and avoid crimping under load during training, especially when fatigued. Warm up thoroughly with general movement, then sport-specific prep like easy bouldering and finger rolls. Avoid sudden spikes in load, build intensity gradually across sessions and weeks. Finally, pay attention to recovery, adequate rest and sleep are as important as training.

responses.resolved_utterance: I am running a 10 miles, can you give me some advice to prepare it
responses.response: Great! Here's a checklist to get you started on your 10-mile training journey: 1. Plan Ahead: Training for a 10-mile run takes time, ideally several months. Start preparing early to build your endurance gradually and safely. 2. Run Slow to Get Strong: Focus on building endurance by running at a comfortable pace. Your long-run pace should be about 1 to 2 minutes per mile slower than your short-run or race pace. Plan a long run every other weekend, increasing the distance by about half a mile each time. The key is consistency and patience. 3. Set Your Own Goals: If you're aged 17 to 21 and in good health, running a 6:30 mile puts you in the top 1% for that age group, according to the U.S. Army standards. That translates to a 1:05:00 finish for 10 miles. But remember that your journey is yours alone. 4. Practice Mid-Run Fuelling: For any run longer than 60 minutes, your body will need fuel. Whether it's energy gels, dates, or other snacks, experiment during training to find what works best for you. Never try something new on race day. 5. Stay Hydrated: A portable water bottle or hydration belt is a must for long runs. Try different setups and go with what feels most comfortable for you. Let me know if you want further help on how to organize your training, for example, how many days per week do you want to train? What time of day works best for you to run? responses.user_utterance: How can I figure out my threshold?
responses.resolved_utterance: How can I figure out my lactate threshold?
responses.response: While exercising above the threshold, more lactate is produced than can be removed from the muscle. A reliable test method for the threshold is the talk test. If you are exercising and can explain easily to someone what you (for example) did on the weekend, you are below the threshold. If you have difficulty explaining, you are at the threshold. And if you can't, then you are above the threshold.

responses.resolved_utterance: I also don't have shoes for my race. Is it important?
responses.response: Running shoes are important because they directly affect your comfort, performance, and risk of injury. If your shoes are not comfortable, it can change the way you run and lead to problems like blisters, joint pain, or muscle strain. Running shoes are specially designed for forward motion and repetitive impact, unlike walking or gym shoes, which may not give the right support. It's also important to choose shoes that match both the size and shape of your foot. Many brands offer different widths to make sure the shoe fits properly. Shoes that are too tight or too loose can cause discomfort or injuries over time. Always use shoes designed for running. Shoe companies spend years researching how to build shoes for specific activities, and wearing the right kind can help you stay healthy and enjoy your runs more. responses.user_utterance: If I decide to change and go for a 5, instead of a 10, would the training change?
responses.resolved_utterance: If I decide to change and go for a 5 km, instead of the 10 km, would the training change?
responses.response: A training plan for a 10 km run will be slightly different from a 5 km training plan. The obvious difference is that a 10 km training plan is longer in duration, and includes longer distance runs each week. The plan may also include other activities like speed workouts, strength training and cross-training depending on your running goals. For a 5 km race, an appropriate interval workout would be: 5 x 3 minutes at 5k race pace with 3 minutes of jogging between runs. For a 10k race, an appropriate interval workout would be: 4 x 5 minutes at 10k race pace with 3 minutes of jogging between runs. Running a 5 km race means you'll run half the 10 km distance at a pace which is about 16 seconds per mile faster than your current 10 km speed. Thus, running a 5 km is a great way to develop the ability to run continuously at a velocity which is significantly faster than your current 10 km pace; each 5 km is in effect a 'stepping stone' to a faster 10 km. As your efficiency at 5 km speed improves, you'll be able to run longer distances at the current 5 km tempo; eventually, you should be able to run your 10 kms at your current 5 km speed (of course, when that happens your 5 kms will be considerably faster). Anyway, all running accomplishments should be celebrated, whether you're crossing the finish line of a mile race or a 50-mile race.

responses.response: If you have time, consider exploring all five boroughs of New York City, each with its own unique vibe. Manhattan is the city's iconic core, with landmarks like Central Park, Times Square, the Empire State Building, and the world-class Metropolitan Museum of Art, which features everything from ancient Egyptian funeral art to contemporary American painting. Cross the Brooklyn Bridge into Brooklyn, known for its creative energy, historic brownstones, and vibrant neighborhoods like Williamsburg. Queens is the city's most diverse borough, offering incredible international food and landmarks like Flushing Meadows-Corona Park. The Bronx, birthplace of hip-hop, is home to Yankee Stadium, the Bronx Zoo, and a strong cultural identity. Staten Island offers a quieter, greener escape with parks, beaches, and stunning views from the free ferry ride past the Statue of Liberty. Together, the five boroughs form a city of endless variety and character.

responses.response: Yes, there is a museum about New York's subways, called the New York Transit Museum. Museums Special interest Boerum Hill New York Transit Museum recounts subway history with a vintage fleet of restored cars that let visitors climb aboard to imagine themselves as straphangers from different decades dating back to the subway opening in 1904. However, the world's first subway was London's Metropolitan Railway that opened in 1863 with steam powered trains.

responses.user_utterance: Why is the subway so important for the city then?
responses.resolved_utterance: Why is the subway so important for the city then, if it is not the world's first?
responses.response: It was the arrival of the subway that transformed a seedy neighborhood called Longacre Square into Times Square, that helped turn a single square mile surrounding the Wall Street station into the center of global finance, that made Coney Island an amusement park for the masses. It was the subway that fuelled the astonishing economic growth that built the city's iconic skyscrapers. Other cities had subways, but none threaded through nearly as many neighborhoods as New York's, enabling it to move large numbers of workers between Manhattan and the middle-class boroughs -- a cycle that repeated itself every day, generating ever more wealth and drawing in ever more people. As New York evolved over the decades, the subway was the one constant, the very thing that made it possible to repurpose 19th-century factories and warehouses as offices or condominiums, or to reimagine a two-mile spit of land between Manhattan and Queens that once housed a smallpox hospital as a high-tech university hub.

responses.user_utterance: Is it the largest in the world?

responses.response: The subway in New York City is the largest subway systems in the world in terms of track mileage and number of stops (472), and one of the only 24 hour subway systems in the world. In comparison, the second place is the one from Shanghai with 345 stations. However, it is not the busiest one, as the one from Beijing had a record of 13 million passengers in a day.

responses.user_utterance: What was the first line?

responses.response: The first portion, from City Hall north to 42nd Street, was opened between 1904 and 1908, and is part of the first subway line in the city.

There is a neighborhood in Manhattan that some of its old timers call "Espana Chica" - Little Spain. From the late 19th century to the present time, it served as the social and cultural nerve center of Spanish immigrants who settled in New York City. Little Spain sits just above the West Village, mostly along West 14th Street, but the casual non-Spanish pedestrian would hardly know they were in a Spanish ethnic enclave. If this stroller were a vexillologist (or a fan of the Real Madrid Soccer team) she would no doubt know that the flag hanging in front of the nondescript brownstone at 239 West 14th Street, home of the Spanish Benevolent Society, was that of Spain. Interestingly, lower-fat milk tends to have slightly more calcium, since milk fat itself doesn't contribute to calcium content.

Swapping out processed ingredients, cutting back on sugar and fat, and skipping artificial colors or sugary toppings can make a big difference. Canola oil is a lighter alternative to butter, with less saturated fat and more heart-friendly monounsaturated fats. For sweeteners, stevia is a top choice, followed by xylitol, erythritol, and yacon syrup. Natural options like honey, molasses or maple syrup are better than white sugar but should still be used in moderation. Yogurt is another great substitute, using one cup of fat-free yogurt instead of oil can lighten the recipe, just be sure to adjust other liquids to avoid an overly wet batter. responses.response: When it comes to sweeteners, stevia is one of the best options. It's a natural, calorie-free sweetener that doesn't raise blood sugar levels and contains compounds like stevioside, which is much sweeter than refined sugar. Maple syrup and honey are also healthier alternatives to white sugar. Maple syrup, especially the darker varieties, contains beneficial antioxidants and minerals such as calcium, magnesium, potassium, and zinc, and has a lower glycemic load than sugar, meaning it causes a slower rise in blood sugar. Honey is richer in antioxidants and also contains small amounts of iron, copper, and phosphorus, but it's slightly higher in calories and carbohydrates. Molasses offers some nutrients too, including iron and calcium, but it's still very high in sugar, so like all sweeteners, it should be used in moderation.

responses.resolved_utterance: I heard so much controversy about breastfeeding. Is it really bad to do it?
responses.response: No, breastfeeding is not bad -- in fact, it's strongly recommended by health experts for both infants and mothers due to its many health benefits. According to the NHMRC, exclusive breastfeeding for around the first six months and continuing up to 12 months or longer provides clear benefits for both infants and mothers. These benefits include optimal nutrition and improved health outcomes in both the short and long term. Similarly, the UK GP Infant Feeding Network notes that breastfeeding plays a crucial role in infant wellbeing, maternal health, and secure infant attachment. They, along with the World Health Organization, recommend exclusive breastfeeding for the first six months, followed by continued breastfeeding alongside solid foods up to 2 years of age or beyond. So, while there may be public controversy or social challenges around breastfeeding, from a medical and health perspective, it is highly beneficial and not harmful.

responses.response: The NHMRC is the National Health and Medical Research Council. According to https://www.healthdirect.gov.au, it is Australia's peak body for supporting health and medical research; for developing health advice for the Australian community, health professionals and governments; and for providing advice on ethical behaviour in health care and in the conduct of health and medical research. Specifically, regular folic acid intake has been linked to reduced levels of birth defects and neural tube defects, making Jasmine rice a good choice. Similarly, cake is not bad. Carbohydrates, which includes cakes, are an important source of folate, a B group vitamin needed for the healthy development of babies in early pregnancy. Folate is important to create DNA and new red blood cells. It helps in reducing inflammation and protects the hearts from cardiovascular issues. It also aids in regulating blood pressure. responses.response: You don't need a special diet while you're breastfeeding - just try to include a well-balanced, healthy variety of the following: Fruit and vegetables, starchy foods (carbohydrates), protein, dairy. You said you are interested in low-carb diets, but a low-carb diet can be dangerous to breastfeeding moms and has been reported to be life-threatening. While breastfeeding you need to drink more than you normally would. It is recommended that nursing moms drink about 12 glasses of water per day to stay well hydrated. The good news is that does not all have to be water. There are many great lactation drinks that can help to stay hydrated and produce more breast milk at the same time. For example, coconut water drinks for breastfeeding, lactation latte, or the breastfeeding protein shake. Importantly, contrary to some beliefs, studies have shown that alcohol interferes with the release of oxytocin which affects the let-down of breast milk, which means that rather than increasing milk supply, breast milk volumes are more likely to be lowered by alcohol.

responses.resolved_utterance: Do you mean that if I drink alcohol I could run out of milk for my baby?
responses.response: Yes, though most mothers can breastfeed and produce enough milk for their babies if they have the right information, support and care. Moreover, each time your baby takes some milk from your breasts, your breasts get the message to make more milk. So, if you are running out of milk you could try fitting in a few extra breastfeeds each day. For example, if you're breastfeeding every 3-4 hours (from the start of one feed to the start of the next), you could try offering the baby a few extra snack breastfeeds in between.

responses.user_utterance: I'm soooooooooooooo excited! What else do I have to know?
responses.resolved_utterance: I'm very excited! What else do I have to know about breastfeeding, given you already told me about diets?
responses.response: Some women get sore, cracked or painful nipples in the early days of breastfeeding. This usually happens if your baby isn't positioned or attached well at the breast. If a baby only sucks the nipple rather than taking a good mouthful of breast, then their tongue or roof of the mouth may rub on the nipple. Your midwife, health visitor or breastfeeding counsellor might be able to help identify any other underlying issues. Some women find rubbing breast milk onto their nipples can be soothing. Products like Vaseline or lanolin can help with dry or cracked nipples (although there's little evidence to show what really works well). After each feed, let your nipples dry before getting dressed - change your breast pads after every feed. Avoid using soap, as this can dry out your skin. If possible, only wear cotton, non-underwired bras. It's best to avoid using nipple shields and breast shells - these will not improve your baby's attachment to the breast. Try not to shorten feeds - doing so will not ease the pain and may reduce your milk supply. Moreover, you do not need to have your baby drink your milk directly. "Expressing" means taking milk from your breast without your baby suckling. You can use a pump or you can do it by hand.

responses.user_utterance: That is good to know! Thanks, now I feel prepared to be a good mum and hope my baby does not need to cry. I know it would break my heart to see him cry! He won't cry often, will he?
responses.resolved_utterance: That is good to know! Thanks, now I feel prepared to be a good mum and hope my baby does not need to cry. I know it would break my heart to see him cry! He won't cry often, will he?
responses.response: You should not worry too much if your baby is crying. Although infants cry for many of the same reasons that adults do, they do it in a way to get our attention. There are actually many reasons why infants cry. Maybe they have a belly ache, they are hungry, something is hurting them, they are scared, but also if they just need to snuggle. responses.response: Microneedling stimulates the production of collagen and elastin. The collagen hydrates the skin cells, making them plump and full. This naturally shrinks the size of the pores, making your skin look flawless and beautiful. Additionally, microneedling addresses dark spots by breaking up melanin clusters and stimulating skin cell regeneration to produce healthy, unpigmented new tissue. CO2 laser treatment is recommended for anyone who is looking to do the following: Minimize the visibility of wrinkles and fine lines on the face. Reduce the appearance of sun-damaged spots, minimize the size of pores, and reduce the overall look and texture of the skin. Achieve an all-over glow plus a younger and healthier appearance.

responses.user_utterance: How does it work?
responses.resolved_utterance: How does CO2 laser treatment work?
responses.response: Which treatment do you mean?

responses.user_utterance: The latter.
responses.resolved_utterance: How does CO2 laser treatment work?
responses.response: CO2 laser treatment uses a beam of light generated by electricity passing through a gas-filled tube. This light is delivered in short, concentrated pulses that target water in the skin, vaporizing damaged surface cells. It removes the top layer of skin, revealing smoother, fresher skin beneath, while also heating deeper layers to stimulate collagen production, which helps tighten and firm the skin over time. The treatment can be quite intense and may require general anaesthesia, especially for deeper procedures. Recovery time varies: fractional treatments might involve a few days of downtime, while fully ablative ones can require up to two weeks. During healing, the skin is typically swollen, scabbed, and raw, often with itching, discomfort, and minor pinpoint bleeding.

responses.user_utterance: That's too much! How about the other method?
responses.resolved_utterance: Two weeks is too much! What is the recovery time of microneedling?
responses.response: Microneedling requires very little downtime. Most people go back to doing their everyday activities after the treatment. However, you will experience some redness and irritation during the first few days. Therefore, you can apply a light layer of BB cream, tinted moisturizer, or light foundation to cover the redness. You should also apply non-comedogenic sunscreen before going outside. As far as healing times go, you can expect a full recovery after about a week. And after 2 to 3 weeks, you'll start seeing the results of the treatment.

responses.user_utterance: What is the difference between fractional and the other type that you mentioned?
responses.resolved_utterance: What is the difference between fractional and ablative treatments?
responses.response: There are two types of CO2 lasers: fully ablative and fractional, with the primary difference being the extent of skin removal, or ablation. Fully ablative CO2 lasers completely remove the superficial skin in the treated area, as their name suggests, while simultaneously heating the deeper dermal layers to stimulate a regenerative healing response that promotes new collagen and elastin production. These treatments tend to be intense, often requiring general anaesthesia, and come with a minimum downtime of about two weeks. However, fully ablative CO2 lasers can paradoxically increase the risk of pigmentation issues and are generally recommended only for individuals with fair or light skin tones.

responses.user_utterance: Are there other techniques?
responses.resolved_utterance: Are there other techniques besides CO2 laser and microneedling?
responses.response: Those with uneven skin color, dark spots, and pigmentation can benefit significantly from chemical peels, which involve applying specific chemicals to peel off the skin's top layer, allowing fresh, exfoliated skin to regenerate. Recovery time varies depending on the peel's depth: light peels typically require about a week, while medium to deep peels may need over a month for full healing. During recovery, it's essential to avoid abrasive skincare products or techniques to allow the skin to heal properly, and extra care must be taken as chemical peels increase sensitivity to sunlight. Another effective option is microdermabrasion, ideal for individuals looking to reduce signs of photoaging, uneven skin tone and texture, such as hyperpigmentation and melasma, fine lines and wrinkles, enlarged pores, atrophic or indented scars (including acne scars), and stretch marks. Safe for all skin types and tones--including darker skin--microdermabrasion works by mechanically buffing the epidermis using a handheld device that sprays exfoliating microcrystals to gently sand away dead skin cells, stimulating new, healthy skin growth. The procedure is generally painless and quick, usually taking around 30 minutes per session. Would you like me to compare these two methods in more detail?

responses.user_utterance: Yes.
responses.resolved_utterance: Yes, compare chemical peel with microdermabrasion.
responses.response: Microdermabrasion and chemical peels are both exfoliative treatments designed to improve skin texture and tone, offering benefits such as tightening the skin, reducing fine lines, evening out skin tone, and minimizing acne scars. While both procedures can be performed in-office by a clinician or at home, they work through different mechanisms: microdermabrasion physically exfoliates by scraping away the topmost layer of skin cells, whereas chemical peels use acid solutions to chemically peel away layers of skin. Chemical peels tend to be more effective for treating acne-prone and sensitive skin, but microdermabrasion is considered safer for darker skin tones. Neither treatment is suitable for all skin types, so careful consideration is needed before choosing one. Both microdermabrasion and light chemical peels can reduce the appearance of large pores--not by shrinking them, which isn't possible, but by clearing excess oil and debris that cause pore dilation, making them appear smaller. Additionally, both treatments help fade dark spots by removing the damaged, pigmented cells in the top layers of skin, allowing healthier new cells to surface. Alternative exfoliating options include laser therapy and at-home treatments, providing a range of choices depending on skin needs and sensitivities.

responses.user_utterance: What are the possible side effects?
responses.resolved_utterance: What are the possible side effects of CO2 laser, microneedling, chemical peeling, and microdermabrasion?
responses.response: Side effects of microdermabrasion may include bruising, redness, swelling, tenderness, and in some cases, petechiae--small dark spots that indicate bleeding under the skin. Chemical peels can cause stinging, swelling, and redness, with the duration of these effects ranging from a few days to several weeks, depending on the strength of the peel. Medium and deep chemical peels carry a higher risk and can potentially lead to bacterial infections, so proper aftercare is essential.

responses.user_utterance: Thanks, but what about the rest?
responses.resolved_utterance: Thanks, but what are the side effects of CO2 laser and microneedling?
responses.response: Side effects of laser skin resurfacing can include stinging, itching, peeling, swelling, and redness. After the procedure, your skin might feel like it's sunburned or remain pink for several months. It may also ooze or blister, and initially, there can be some darkening of the skin. Swelling is common for a day or two following the treatment. On the other hand, microneedling side effects may include peeling, bruising, bleeding, and a risk of bacterial infection. Redness after microneedling is normal and usually lasts only a few hours, typically subsiding by the next day. Other common effects include tingling sensations and slight dryness as the skin heals and exfoliates.

responses.user_utterance: Microneedling sounds good. Can I have my routine after doing it?
responses.resolved_utterance: The microneedling treatment seems good to me. Can I have my routine after doing it?
responses.response: Hyaluronic acid is the ultimate post-microneedling ingredient to look for, as it is a naturally occurring substance in the body known for its powerful hydrating and skin-replenishing properties. Applying hyaluronic acid after microneedling enhances its absorption, allowing the serum or treatment to penetrate deeper and work more effectively due to the temporary micro-channels created in the skin. However, it's crucial to avoid applying retinol, makeup, and strong exfoliating acids such as AHAs (alpha hydroxy acids) and BHAs (beta hydroxy acids) immediately after microneedling, as these can cause irritation or even worsen skin sensitivity. It's recommended to wait at least 24 hours post-treatment before using makeup to avoid introducing pore-clogging or irritating ingredients into freshly treated skin. If you use exfoliants containing AHAs like lactic, glycolic, or mandelic acid, apply them either the day before microneedling or wait at least two days after a session--especially when using devices like the Banisher. Additionally, while Vitamin C is a popular antioxidant, it can be sensitizing for some individuals post-microneedling, so it's best to use a gentle, naturally derived, or specifically formulated version to reduce the risk of irritation.

Mesotherapy, on the other hand, involves injecting a blend of vitamins, hyaluronic acid, and other nutrients directly into the skin to boost hydration, radiance, and superficial rejuvenation. If your goal is deeper skin renewal and firming, microneedling may be more effective. For added glow and hydration, mesotherapy is a great choice. Some people combine both treatments for more comprehensive results.

responses.user_utterance: Hi, how can I find a good shampoo for my hair?
responses.resolved_utterance: Hi, how can I find a good shampoo for my hair?
responses.response: When choosing a shampoo for an oily scalp, opt for products labelled "volumizing," "strengthening," or "balancing," as these are typically formulated to manage excess oil without adding unnecessary weight. Avoid shampoos that advertise moisturizing, hydrating, or smoothing effects, as well as those designed for curly or frizzy hair--these formulas tend to be too rich and can make oily hair feel heavy or greasy. Look for labels that specifically mention "for oily hair" or highlight oil-controlling and balancing benefits. It's also wise to consider anti-dandruff shampoos, since dandruff is not always a result of dryness; it's often triggered by microscopic fungi that thrive on excess scalp oil, leading to irritation and flaking. For a deeper cleanse, you can occasionally use a clarifying shampoo to remove buildup but limit its use to avoid over-drying or irritating the scalp.

responses.user_utterance: How about the formulation of shampoo? Should I look for any specific ingredients?
responses.resolved_utterance: How about the formulation of shampoo? Should I look for any specific ingredients suitable for my hair?
responses.response: To help manage an oily scalp, look for shampoos that contain cleansing agents such as sodium lauryl sulphate, ammonium-based compounds, or other effective detergents, as these can help dry out excess oil. Sulfosuccinates are another group of detergents known for their ability to remove buildup without being overly harsh. Salicylic acid is especially effective, as it breaks down oil on the scalp more thoroughly than standard shampoo ingredients. Additionally, natural ingredients like echinacea and sage work to refresh the scalp, slough off dead skin cells, and keep pores and sweat glands clear of obstruction. Tea tree oil is also beneficial, as it actively dissolves and washes away oil and debris, promoting a cleaner and healthier scalp environment.

responses.user_utterance: I have also heard that shampoos with niacinamide and Lactic Acid or LHA are useful. Any other tips for treating it?

responses.response: To manage an oily scalp, try to limit the use of heat styling tools--excessive heat can strip the scalp of its natural oils, triggering it to produce even more oil in response. When conditioning, apply a small amount only to the mid-lengths and ends of your hair--never the scalp--as this can cause buildup, greasiness, and even contribute to hair fall or bacterial growth. Washing your hair about three times per week is usually ideal: frequent cleansing helps control oil, but daily washing may overstimulate sebum production. Keep your pillowcases, bedsheets, and hairbrushes clean, as they can harbour oil and bacteria that contribute to scalp issues. Your diet also plays a key role--limit oily and fried foods and focus instead on healthy fats (like those from nuts or fish) and complex carbs to support balanced sebum levels. If a distracting thought pops up, just jot it down on a notepad to deal with later and gently guide your focus back to the task. When the timer goes off, you take a 5-minute break. This can be especially helpful in a sedentary office job, as you can use that break to stand up and stretch. These breaks also provide a natural opportunity to switch tasks if you feel your focus waning. After four Pomodoros, you take a longer break of 15-30 minutes. responses.resolved_utterance: Tell me more about needle types for tattooing.
responses.response: Understanding tattoo needle types is crucial for achieving different effects in your artwork, even on fake skin. It's a bit like choosing the right brush for a painting! Tattoo needles are generally categorized by their configuration (grouping). There are Round Liners (RL), Round Shaders (RS), Stacked Magnum (M1), Round Magnum and Flat Needles. Round Liners are primarily used for outlining the design. They come in various sizes, affecting the thickness of the line. These include 3RL, 5RL, 7RL, and even larger groupings, with the number indicating how many needles are in the grouping. Round Shaders are designed for shading or colouring between the lines of the RL outline. Similar to RL, they come in different sizes, like 5RS or 7RS. Stacked Magnum are best suited for blending and shading smaller areas while Round Magnum are for colouring in larger areas without overworking the skin. Finally, Flat Needles are used for shapes and intricate shading, like geometric designs or bold lines. As a hobbyist, starting with a few common types like a 3RL or 5RL for lines, and a 7RS or 9M1 for shading, would give you a good range to experiment with on your fake skin. Focus on understanding how each type feels and how it deposits ink, and you'll quickly develop a feel for what works best for different design elements.

responses.user_utterance: What is reach?
responses.resolved_utterance: What does REACH compliant in tattooing stand for?
responses.response: REACH compliance refers to the European Union's regulation on the Registration, Evaluation, Authorisation and Restriction of Chemicals. It ensures that chemicals used in products, including tattoo inks and needles, are safe for human health and the environment. When a product is REACH compliant, it means that it has been tested and meets the safety standards set by the EU. This is particularly important in tattooing, as the inks and materials used can have direct contact with the skin. Using REACH compliant products helps ensure that you are using safe and regulated materials, which is especially crucial when you eventually move from practicing on fake skin to real skin.

responses.response: Indeed, related to the chain it might be wear, or the chain being not on the correct length. It can also be the teeth of your cassette being damaged. Can you tell me more about your bike, did you buy it recently? or changed some parts recently?

responses.resolved_utterance: I have problem with the chain of my bike, it could be chain wear or an issue with the chain length. I bought this bike one month ago, the chain was changed when I bought it, and the gear doesn't look damaged.
responses.response: Then it is probably not worn, and more likely a problem of chain length. The next step would be to check the length of the chain. To do that, go on the largest chairing and largest cog, you should be able to do the shift easily. On the other side, go on the smallest cog, there you should see that the jockey still has some tension. Let me know once you did those two steps if you notice something abnormal.

responses.user_utterance: Wait, what is the jockey?
responses.resolved_utterance: Wait, what is the jockey within a bike?
responses.response: Your rear derailleur features an upper and a lower jockey wheel, and these perform different jobs. The upper jockey wheel, also known as the guide pulley, is the one that is in charge of shifting duties when you change speed. The lower jockey wheel is also known as the tension pulley, because it helps to keep the chain tensioned in each gear combination. Both are two small wheels next to your gears on the back wheel.

responses.user_utterance: I tried to go on the largest gears, and I see that the chain seems a bit loose. How to know the perfect length?
responses.resolved_utterance: I tried to go on the largest gears of my bike, and I see that the chain seems a bit loose. How to know the perfect length of a chain for a bike?
responses.response: If your chain feels loose on the largest gears, it might be too long. One way to check the ideal chain length is by using this formula: L = 2(C) + (F/4 + R/4 + 1) where: L is the chain length in inches, C is the distance from the crank center to the rear axle (the chain stay), F is the number of teeth on the largest front chainring, R is the number of teeth on the largest rear cog. You can measure the chain stay and count the teeth on your gears to calculate it. Let me know if you'd like help doing this step by step or identifying these parts on your bike.

responses.user_utterance: I'm not good with math
responses.resolved_utterance: I'm not good with math. Is there not an easier way to know the perfect chain length on a bike, other than using a formula?
responses.response: Ok. here is another more hands-on method, also very reliable, called the big-big method. You can remove your chain from the gears, and from the derailleur, then wrap the chain against the largest front chainring and rear cog, skipping the derailleur, and then pull it tight. This gives you the reference length, on which you can add two extra links. Do you have a chain breaker tool to do it? I would also advise you to use a bike repair stand if you have one, it might avoid you some back pain.

responses.user_utterance: That's much better, thanks, yes I have a chain breaker, but you can remind me how to use it, and also how to open my chain?
responses.resolved_utterance: That's much better, thanks, yes I have a chain breaker, but you can remind me how to use it, and also how to open my bike chain?
responses.response: You should be able to identify a master link on your chain - a special link that join the two ends of the chain. Once you identified the master link, you can open your chain, then use the chain breaker to remove the number of links you need. To remove the links, you just need to align the chain breaker with a pivot/pin or a link and then push the pin out, once the pin is out, the link will automatically drop.

responses.user_utterance: Thanks, great it worked. What should I use to lubricate my chain now? Can I use car oil?
responses.resolved_utterance: Thanks, great I manage to change my bike chain, it worked. What should I use to lubricate my chain now? Can I use car oil?
responses.response: You could use motor oil, but it is not the ideal case because bike and car oils have different properties. Car motor oil is made to resist to extreme temperature, while bike grease needs to resist to water. If you apply your grease correctly, you could easily bike for 200 miles without any problem, while with poor quality oil, you might have to do extra maintenance.

responses.user_utterance: How to know when to add grease again?
responses.resolved_utterance: How to know when to add grease on bike chain?
responses.response: Since you ride a mountain bike on dirty or muddy terrain, you should clean and re-grease your chain frequently--ideally after every muddy ride or every 50-100 miles. Dirt and debris can cause fast wear and poor shifting if not removed. In contrast, city or road bikes used in cleaner conditions can go up to 400-500 miles between lubrications. Always check your chain--if it looks dry, sounds squeaky, or feels gritty, it's time to clean and lube it. Regular maintenance keeps your drivetrain smooth and lasting longer.
